p: While Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) did not differ significantly between the 2 groups, patients with confirmed CHIKV infection frequently presented with severe musculoskeletal pain and central nervous system (CNS) related symptoms (such as altered mentation, confusion and loss of consciousness): this difference was statistically significant with a p-value of 0.001. Gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms including nausea, abdominal pain and vomiting were reported in 53.8% of DENV patients (p<0.001) ( Table 2). Haemorrhage was significantly associated with DENV virus infection with 8% of patients presenting with this symptom (p = 0.040) ( Table 2). Rash was seen in 15.3% and 15.2% of CHIKV and DENV cases respectively and was not a significant predictor of disease ( Table 2).
